p.s: The excerpt at hand, dealing with the escalation of the dinner and Amir's sudden outbreak of violence, is very crucial for the drama and to get a better understanding of Amir's character.
In the same place it's a turning point.
In the following I am going to do ana detailled examination of the scene and Amir's emotional outbursts.
First of all it is significant to mention the general change of behavior of all the characters in this excerpt.
While they just discussed about their different opinions mainly about Islam, there is a conflict where they shout, spit and acting violently.
Jory is very angry about her husband and Emily lying at her: What the fuck is going on here? (p. 71, l. 21).
The vulgar words revealsreveal her shock.
Emily gets hysterical when her husband walks in because she fears he could believe Jory.
Her incredulous shouts, prove this fear (p. 72, ll. 7-8).
She manipulates Amir within telling him she was emotionally overwhelmed with the fact that Jory got the job instead of Amir (p. 72, ll. 2-4).
This makes Amir believe her and being even more angry about Jory.

In general, one can say that Amir tries hard to get rid offof Islam because of obsoleted punishments in the quaranQuran, anti-semitism and mysogony he experienced in the islamicIslamic communitycommunnity.
Additionally, he made other bad experiences in his childhood.
The first two scenes of the drama reveal the effort and struggles Amir has to fully get rid offof the ingrained cultural values of Islam.
He criticises her mother for teaching him to spit on Jews and the quaranQuran saying wife-beating is an option.
In this scene the impuls of the values comes back again, when he loses control.
This happens twice: it happens once when he spits in Isaac's face (p. 72, l. 40).

Especially this behavior reveals Amir's surpressedsuppressed islamicIslamic values and refers to a memory of his childhood where his mother spat in his face after Amir telling her he had a crush on a jewishJewish girl.
This is up to this point Amir could stand his anger but the several circumstances coming together at one evening are like an emotional outburst.
These circumstances that triggered him were for example the injustices and islamophobia at his work because Jory got a job should be supposed to get.
He believes the happening that happened as an act at islamophobia.
The fact that Jory is African-American lets him call himself with the n-word (p. 72, l. 29).
This makes the reader realise that Amir thinks he has more to suffer from islamophobia than Jory from racism against black people.
The affair he becomes aware of leads Amir to get completely out of control and hitting his wife Emily (p. 74, l. 6).
His behavior is the complete opposite of the man he wants to be after critisizing the quaranQuran for the point wife-beating.
In general one can see that Amir and Isaac both act discriminating.
Isaac hurts perjuges at Amir as if he represents the muslimMuslim community: There's a reason they call you people animals (p. 73, l. 1).
To sum up it can be said that the unconscious and surpressed prejuges or hate of Isaac and Amir against the religions Islam and Jewishness comes up as a consult of integrated cultural values.
